reviews.text: It may not always sing like a songbird when taken as a whole, but The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes still packs a venomous bite at its best.
reviews.author: Calum Cooper

reviews.text: ...retains the hard edge that made most of these movies register as piercing satires of our reality-television age.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Ballad sanitizes its brutality for a PG-13 rating and diminishes the story’s sense of high-stakes survive-or-die suspense, and Francis Lawrence’s approach to action sequences is bland and uninspired, a reflection of the film’s generic visual aesthetic.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: A surprisingly bleak yet narratively elemental mishmash of derivative dystopian tropes, the film's real subversion exists in the delightfully garish and incredibly callous supporting characters bedazzling the decadent capital of Panem.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: While many critics have carped about the decision to hand an entire film over to a character everyone knows will turn evil (apparently, these critics never heard of the Star Wars prequels), the truth is that it’s surprisingly compelling.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Aside from an interesting and somewhat original story,  The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes has a wonderful cast that includes younger thespians mixed with seasoned veterans.
reviews.author: Allison Rose

reviews.text: Gives a backstory that fleshes out the franchise a little more – and quite honestly, ups the ante. It’s beautifully shot, well-acted, really engaging, and makes for an excellent reason to go to the movies.
reviews.author: Paul Salfen

reviews.text: There’s still space in this world for the lessons The Hunger Games can teach us about the way we consume media and news, but The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is not clear enough in its vision to be as impactful as its predecessors.
reviews.author: Tina Kakadelis

reviews.text: An involving prequel that understands the troubling politics buckling a society of inequality and gets brutal when necessary in its depiction of the games. Despite a bit muddled third act its an engrossing prologue.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes will cater to tributes, but the unnecessarily long prequel can’t flesh out a one-dimensional villain with a rise and fall narrative in which to emotionally invest.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: Much better than expected and featuring two stand out performances and a world that I find very interesting overall.
reviews.author: Brian Gill

reviews.text: A prequel to the four-film series that provides the origin story for the evil ruler of Panen.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: The ”snakes” of the title may refer to that mass of multicoloured serpents Dr. Gaul wants to unleash on the hapless tributes, but it’s just as easy to see Coryo as the snake to Lucy Grey’s songbird.
reviews.author: John McDonald

reviews.text: [It] has a decent number of exciting, breathtaking moments, as the Games play themselves out. But they can’t sustain that intensity for the full movie, which finds itself borrowing from the past.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: This film questions what you will do in times of stress: Will you kill when it is the only way to survive, be loyal when it is time to be loyal, fight for love when it might mean death? It is interesting, exciting and looks so good on the big screen
reviews.author: Reginald Ponder

reviews.text: Set sixty-four years before the triumph of Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), the clever screenplay reflects the violence assimilated by the culture. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Aglaia Berlutti

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is more focused on delivering Easter eggs with the subtlety of a sledgehammer than developing these characters. It leaves us with nearly three hours of brand revival.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: The fun performances by a game cast can't make up for poor pacing and a bloated runtime that feels wholly unearned.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: It’s still just a slightly modernized, teen-oriented take on "Rollerball" or “The Running Man.”
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: THE HUNGER GAMES: THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES is an incredible extension of the series, both in terms of structure and theme.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: A reasonably compelling narrative about a conflicted young man, a man torn between his ambitious nature and his moral compass and feelings for a charming and beautiful young woman.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: [R]evisiting the original series’ ideas and themes leads to diminishing dramatic and emotional returns, but as a case study in authoritarian politics, [this film] remains as relevant today as it was fifteen years ago when the first novel was published.
reviews.author: Mel Valentin

reviews.text: An entertaining installment that may not be quite as good as the originals, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes definitely stands on its own merits and charm.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: Were we champing at the bit to learn how Donald Sutherland’s Machiavellian President Coriolanus Snow schemed his way to power in the years before the original The Hunger Games
reviews.author: Travis Johnson

reviews.text: Needs no more installments.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Years after the young-adult dystopia genre crested and flattened, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is here to remind us of what we are missing: not much.
reviews.author: Morgan Shaunette

reviews.text: The best film in the series — but that’s still not saying much.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: The action scenes remain well-shot and tightly edited, and even without the provocative political energy of the Katniss years, the cultural parallels between Panem’s world and ours retain their unsettling power.
reviews.author: Elizabeth Weitzman

reviews.text: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a film of contrasts — visually stunning yet narratively uneven, it offers a fascinating glimpse into the origins of Panem, but not without stumbling over its own ambitious intentions.
reviews.author: Valerie Complex

reviews.text: I do not buy it philosophically for one second.
reviews.author: Tim Cogshell

reviews.text: It is very long and sometimes unwieldy, but in the hands of director Francis Lawrence... I think fans will like it. It delivers mostly the high notes you expect from a film of this sort.
reviews.author: Lael Loewenstein

reviews.text: A standout leading lady isn't quite enough to rescue Songbirds and Snakes from sluggish runtime, bizarre pacing, and muddled thematic elements, but Zegler's fire (combined with some memorable costuming and action set pieces) lends this film some spark.
reviews.author: Lauren Coates

reviews.text: Absolutely zero chemistry between the two leads.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text:
The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is enjoyable and recaptures the essence of the series. Can be bloated at times but the performances and script carry the film home.

Themes of oppression, dystopia, and societal inequity are relevant to today’s injustices.
reviews.author: Sheraz Farooqi

reviews.text: The film is compelling and dark, and benefits from an impressive cast including Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage, plus evocative production design and some gut-wrenching twists.
reviews.author: Dave Golder

reviews.text: It’s really just a tired rehash, albeit an extravagant one, this time with less appealing characters. As dystopias go, it’s a real bummer.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: This time, the music plays a central character that makes this prequel all the more welcome.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: ...the ruthless intrigue of a post-war Capitol is a brilliant allegory for how the scramble for power ultimately makes spectacles of us all. The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a villan origin story you shouldn't miss.
reviews.author: Ro Moore

reviews.text: This is a strong movie filled with excitement, tension, and drama that will keep you watching. The performances are excellent, the screenplay is fantastic, and Lawrence shines again as a superb director.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: A fascinating character study of a villain made not born... Collins has graduated to an entirely new level of storytelling in this genre: an introspection into a single character whose fate is known... easily the best film of the series.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes stumbles in adaptation from book to film primarily in the structure, and while it also runs too long, it's not a bad return to this world for those familiar with this franchise or those who know nothing.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: A strong addition to the franchise - though the need to justify the existence of the story is a fair discussion to have, especially without further sequels currently lined up. If potential future stories can be as strong as this, however, count me in.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: The story here is strong enough to stand on its own, but of course, it is a prequel, and there is a grimy pleasure in seeing the clunky early iterations of the later Games’ slick social machinations.
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: I didn’t expect to walk out of a Hunger Games movie with a roots music buzz, but I’m not complaining!
reviews.author: Sara Stewart

reviews.text: Essentially the “Star Wars” prequels of the “Hunger Games” world. But while George Lucas took three movies to show us Anakin’s fall into darkness, Lawrence and screenwriters Michael Lesslie and Michael Arndt try to do it in one overstuffed installment.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: Viewers have already seen these narrative machinations and limited themes leeched for every ounce of meaning across the original series, but here we are again, chewing on the exact same discursive material like a cow with their cud.
reviews.author: Luke Gorham

reviews.text: 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes' makes it through as becoming one of the more memorable films of 2023. Despite its languish pace and a hard-to-sell romance, it’s action-packed and worthy of recognition.
reviews.author: Josie Meléndez

reviews.text: If you've not read the book, or seen the previous movies, you won't get as much out of it. The first 2/3 of the movie is slow, plodding, and violent. The 3rd act becomes more interesting as we see the arc of Rachel Ziegler character, along with Snow's.
reviews.author: Michael Cook

reviews.text: Overall, there's plenty to appreciate about the movie -- the performances, the production design, Nashville producer/songwriter Dave Cobb's music supervision, and the many Easter eggs and references for Hunger Games fans.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: Though the nearly three-hour runtime certainly seems daunting, the characters and music, to say nothing of the tense, action-packed event that is the Hunger Games, drive this film forward and deliver a powerful tale from a beloved universe.
reviews.author: Jules Caldeira

reviews.text: Surrounded by stellar performances from a cast committed to bringing Snow’s origin to life, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a magnificent prequel to a franchise that ruled over the big screen over a decade ago.
reviews.author: Diego Peralta

reviews.text: 'Songbirds & Snakes' won't make you feel any more resentful of the fact that fictitious barbaric competition exists inside this world, but perhaps it will make you understand why it was able to grow into the thing we know in later stories.
reviews.author: Murjani Rawls

reviews.text: As before, director Francis Lawrence remains faithful to Suzanne Collins' novel, with high-quality filmmaking and solid performances. But there's little air in the story, as the script races along with an over-serious tone.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes isn’t bad...But when the entire point of the movie is to be an origin story for a villain, that part of it should work better than anything else. And, in our minds, it’s the opposite.
reviews.author: Germain Lussier

reviews.text: Praise Davis, Schafer and Schwartzman, who understand the film they're in and embrace it. Blyth is afraid to let Snow be a villain so the romance between him and Zegler only works during the games. Overall, this is fine, but too long, especially Part 3
reviews.author: Joe Lipsett

reviews.text: The prequel is much more layered than the Jennifer Lawrence films. Actor Tom Blyth is mesmerizing in the role with deep, soulful eyes that convey his thoughts and feelings. Viola Davis also shines as the mad scientist who shapes Snow into the President.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. It’s deeply mesmerizing and engrossing. You will not be disappointed in this trip to the Districts.
reviews.author: Benjamin Franz

reviews.text: Full of standout performances from the entire cast and an affecting story about the lengths people are willing to go to not just for survival but for power, The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is an impressively haunting character study.
reviews.author: Gissane Sophia

reviews.text: The richest and most meaningful film of the entire franchise. A heartbreaker with beautiful highs and devastating lows
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: Yet [Coriolanus Snow's] links to the story’s future aren’t enough to make him fascinating here. Thank goodness for Rachel Zegler, who plays a woman fighting for her life.
reviews.author: Edward Porter

reviews.text: For a dystopic action drama with a "modest" $100 million budget, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes looks good enough. Paces itself well enough. And pretty much always strives to just be enough. And for me that’s also enough.
reviews.author: Jon Negroni

reviews.text: At every turn, the film makes a strange choice either in screenplay or filmmaking to undercut itself.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: Solid return to Panem. Most of the movie delivered what I was wanting. But this feels like a rare example of a film which would have been better served split into two films. The odd structures causes the film to run out of momentum long before it's over.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: Director Francis Lawrence does an incredible job with this novel adaptation and Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler have electric chemistry in this Hunger Games prequel.
reviews.author: Lauren Veneziani

reviews.text: It’s haunting without losing the balance of its sappy romance and battle royale shenanigans. It sparks renewed enthusiasm for a more mature audience, providing focus on the story’s astute power dynamics and the unraveling of bureaucratic hypocrisies.
reviews.author: Ryan Oquiza

reviews.text: I’ve always found The Hunger Games to be more than passable entertainment for a franchise that I paradoxically thought did nothing particularly well.
reviews.author: Kenneth R. Morefield

reviews.text: Strong performances, melancholic melodies, psychologically twisted storytelling, boldly biting scenes, fantastic aesthetics and production value make 'Songbirds and Snakes' a vigorously engrossing and victorious return of “The Hunger Games.”
reviews.author: Nathalia Aryani

reviews.text: Despite its racial diversity, the film employs the safe but shallow "colorblind" approach that blunts its positive effects.
reviews.author: Li Lai

reviews.text: As far as pointless prequels go, this one kept me interested without pandering to the previous entries in the series. Not amazing but definitely a solid 1-time watch.
reviews.author: Adam Olinger

reviews.text: Nothing leaps off the screen, few things feel dire, little happens to make us truly care about the characters or their situational struggles.
reviews.author: Michael Ward

reviews.text: Despite the socialist rigors and humanitarian wrongs, it feels good to be back in Panem, a world that rolls deep like a familiar melody but slithers slyly with a new tale of forbidden love, opportunistic alliances and a deadly game.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: The new addition to the saga entertains, but only scratches the surface of what could have been an interesting transformation.
reviews.author: Orlando Maldonado

reviews.text: Davis’s deranged games designer Dr Volumnia Gaul and Jason Schwartzman’s showboating compere Lucky Flickerman justify the price of admission.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: While I’m pretty sure Lionsgate bankrolled the project in the hope that another title under the Hunger Games umbrella might be profitable, the production is of comparable quality to the earlier releases even if its need to exist is questionable.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes doesn't feel like a rehash. The story centered on young President Snow is pretty captivating.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: Despite Tom Blyth's best efforts, this film can't deliver a compelling villain origin story. This is yet another unneeded, underwhelming, and uninteresting prequel trying desperately to keep a franchise monetizable.
reviews.author: Alachia Queen

reviews.text: Tom Blyth is a revelation as the complex young Coriolanus Snow, delivering one of the best performances of the year, [while] elevating important pieces of The Hunger Games lore to new heights.
reviews.author: Kristen Maldonado

reviews.text: In a pivotal scene in this banal, dull, boring prequel in which poisonous snakes are slithering all over her, the heroine bursts into song, making me want to stuff a sock in her mouth!
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: A highly entertaining film with the signature, luscious costumes and sets, this "Hunger Games" prequel nevertheless stumbles with the uneven story of the franchise's main villain's origin story
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes never surpasses the original Hunger Games films, but succeeds as a return to the world of Panem, full of propaganda strategizing, brutal violence involving teens, and a splash of romance.
reviews.author: Kyle Logan

reviews.text: If you push the tired prequel tropes aside, The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a rather triumphant comeback for The Hunger Games franchise...
reviews.author: Sarah El-Mahmoud

reviews.text: It fails to validate its existence beyond the Hollywood routine of squeezing every dollar out of a successful franchise. It doesn’t really add anything to the overall narrative. It’s just… more story. And for no reason at all.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: …just about works as a stand-alone film, with obvious symbolism and sharp pretentions that few blockbusters can offer… doubling down on the dark, vain-glorious reasons that a well-meaning man might find himself fast becoming a new Hitler for his age...
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: "Ballad" may be bloated, but it understands that The Hunger Games, as a franchise, didn’t succeed because it had a clear political philosophy. It succeeded because it entertained.
reviews.author: Shirley Li

reviews.text: It was long but sharper than expected, esp. Rachel Zegler as Lucy, who had an edge to her survivalist and performed a singing angle to great effectiveness. And Peter Dinklage can do more with a raised eyebrow than most actors can do with grand speech.
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: At 157 minutes, it’s overlong, but Blyth and Zegler have chemistry and real acting chops, and his not-so-heroic journey is a nicely nuanced portrait of how someone started out before breaking bad.
reviews.author: Dana Kennedy

reviews.text: If, like me, you are a fan of the first films and books, it is enjoyable to be back in this dystopian world. Even if you are not quite sure why.
reviews.author: Grant Rollings

reviews.text: Some muscular central performances and a firecracker finale nudge this Hunger Games prequel away from the worst instincts of the franchise.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: Rather than splitting a book into two dull, overlong, and bloated films, they’ve just made one dull, overlong, and bloated film.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: All up, the film is among the more laboured and contrived than the series. There’s not much wit in it.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a great follow-up to the earlier films and works very well on its own. It might be the best crowd-pleaser of the Thanksgiving season.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: [O]ne of the most exciting, emotionally arresting entries in the franchise.
reviews.author: Shannon Campe

reviews.text: [Viola] Davis and [Rachel] Zegler steal every single frame they’re in, chewing up the scenery and delivering such amazing performances as to not be forgotten for some time.
reviews.author: Courtney Lanning

reviews.text: If you bought into the first four instalments, then you will doubtless have fun, but it seemed to me to go on for ever...
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes wants to make a point about how Panem divides Snow and Lucy, but as serviceable as Blyth and Zelger are as performers, their actual love story needs to be believable for us to notice.
reviews.author: Roxana Hadadi

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is the result of [Hollywood's] financial ambitions. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fran Chico

reviews.text: Prequels are generally trash, movie musicals are messy, and villain-centric narratives are almost always disturbingly sympathetic to wretched ideals. This is a villain-centric prequel with enough singing to count as a quasi-musical. It’s somehow great?
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: This latest installment in the dystopian fantasy franchise emphasizes spectacle over substance, rehashing many of the same plots and themes with fresh faces and a few familiar names.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: This is a dour, depressing tale about an expanding dystopia, centered on a protagonist who’s learning how to prosper in a dog-eat-dog world.  What’s not to like?
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Far better than anticipated, Francis Lawrence’s “Hunger Games” prequel, “The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes” proves to be a worthy addition to the franchise, one that reminds us of what made these stories distinctive among the rash of YA dystopian novels,
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Remarkably, Songbirds & Snakes has found a way to make the Hunger Games feel new and sharp.
reviews.author: Alex Abad-Santos

reviews.text: The film should have ended at the two-hour mark and saved the last material for another film where the dramatic shift the characters make could be expanded to a more understandable level.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: A mediocre prequel that feels even longer than it actually is due to the baffling structural decision of adding a third act that feels like the second season of a tv series. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: This Hunger Games prequel provides intriguing performances and some insight into the early days of Panem, but fails to keep the momentum throughout.
reviews.author: Jon Mendelsohn

reviews.text: Francis Lawrence's Return to Panem takes us even deeper into dystopia through the youth of President Snow: the youth of a leader we all love to hate. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yago García

reviews.text: "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is two-thirds of a crowd-pleasing grand adventure that gets bogged down by the obligations of being a prequel.
reviews.author: Derek Deskins

reviews.text: Overindulgent...a bloated origin story...
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: This grittier, more intimate realization of Panem compels. When the turnstiles into the arena cheerily chirp “enjoy the show”, the franchise’s dichotomy of spectacle and savagery is underscored with renewed resonance.
reviews.author: Thomas Floyd

reviews.text: Luckily, the intrinsic force of the events that transpire prevents the film from sinking at any point, but the idea behind the story is a thousand times more powerful than the way it's executed. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: Reservations aside, the most important aspect to this film is that it makes me curious and gets me excited about what comes next.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: The Hunger Games is back on the big screen, but prequel adaptation The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes can't quite scale the heights of either its source material or its cinematic predecessors.
reviews.author: Zach Kram

reviews.text: Completely unnecessary and mostly lifeless prequel. Davis is only saving grace.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: It’s another heady mix of teen romance, glamorous frocks, dark comedy, gruesome slayings and social commentary.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Adaptations, particularly those based on books that primarily use inner dialogue, are difficult and although this picture hits all the novel’s major events, there is definitely something lost in translation, which could leave some viewers in the dark.
reviews.author: Sarah Gopaul

reviews.text: At nearly three-hours long, the movie gives you too much of some things and not nearly enough of others. Still, for all its flaws, at least critics can't say, "It didn't follow the book."
reviews.author: Matthew Huff

reviews.text: I wouldn't say that Songbirds is dreadful, but like its lynchpin performer Jennifer Lawrence, it probably should have moved on. What's the point?
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Readers, fans and followers of the series will certainly get more out of the film, but even those who are completely unfamiliar with the Hunger Games franchise will appreciate this movie for what it is—a compelling dystopian fantasy.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: I'm taken by its attempt at being the Lawrence of Arabia of YA movies, and its exploration of how tyranny is fuelled by self-preservation and how people condone state-sanctioned violence out of fear and desperation. That conversation really hits today.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: Franchise fans looking to revisit this world will get enough to make it worth it. For everyone else: Leave when the Chapter 3 title card appears.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: It’s a risk doing a prequel to this hit film franchise without the power engine of star Jennifer Lawrence and the safe and sorry result, set 64 years before Lawrence's Katniss Everdeen ever drew breath, is seriously overlong and underwhelming.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: Its 2-hour-and-37-minute runtime starts to drag by the end. This is mostly due to the fact that the film sticks too close to the book. The action takes place in the first two-thirds, and then we get a sort of extended epilogue.
reviews.author: Collin Garbarino

reviews.text: It looks like no Katniss is no problem for Songbirds And Snakes. A fine blockbuster adventure for autumn
reviews.author: Lou Thomas

reviews.text: Even if you’ve only seen one of these films, you won’t need to spend 156 minutes witnessing the rise of a madman whose actions never required any backstory in the first place.
reviews.author: Odie Henderson

reviews.text: Whereas many of these prequels feel like crass cash-ins, "Songbirds & Snakes" stands on its own as an absorbing story with a terrific new character, just to the left of the lead.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes? More like Ballad of Yawns & Snore.
reviews.author: Kshitij Rawat

reviews.text:
It’s a long, slow, expensive-looking haul so light on ideas it raises the legitimate question: do we really need more Hunger Games? Really?
Another question the film raises – is Rachel Zegler still a thing?
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: Possibly the least catchy movie title of the year, but maybe the most pleasant surprise.
reviews.author: Tanner Gordon

reviews.text: A tale that has the potential to be fiery with feelings and soulful decimation, but “Songbirds & Snakes” is mostly dull and definitely overlong.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Fans of the series and the book will appreciate this faithful version, but others may find the relentless butchery outweighs the lessons about morality, trust, and resilience.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: It is possible, the movie suggests, to do something as cynical as a franchise prequel with care and insight, to further expand on intellectual property in ways that actually enrich the original product.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes might issue a siren song to curious Hunger Games fans, but for those on the fringes, it’s not a call worth answering.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Luckily, Blyth is savvy enough to not lean into the mustache-twirling or the telegraphing of horrors to come... Both the actor and "Ballad" seem to respect the fans and the franchise.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: This more than 2.5 hour film would rank as one of Hollywood’s sleepiest fantasy blockbusters of the century even without the pointless musical interludes, of which there are at least half a dozen.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is an engaging, gritty, and entertaining prequel that takes a significant leap by strategically focusing on the politics of the Panem Capitol... [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Laia Cabuli

reviews.text: It's not terrible or great, but this Hunger Games prequel has enough thrilling action sequences and interpersonal drama to satisfy most Hunger Games fans. Viewers who are unfamiliar with the franchise might be confused or feel disconnected from the story.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: Despite the lacking wrap-up, “Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes” is, like most of the “Hunger Games” films, a well-made dystopian yarn that’s better acted than it needs to be.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: It's a decent ride, for what it's worth, with strong production values and credible performances from a set of committed actors. But there is a nagging sense that... we're participating in an exercise of corporate IP simply for corporate IP's sake.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: It is not necessary to have seen the original tetralogy to enjoy the prequel, which expands the universe of the dystopian saga and remains firmly established as one of the best franchises of the genre. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Andrea Zamora

reviews.text: The origin of the Games, its media connotations, the intrigues, the betrayals and everything that District 12 means, appears here displayed with great narrative skill, cunning, and an adequate sense of entertainment. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Marcelo Stiletano

reviews.text: Though as a piece of filmmaking it isn’t bad, there’s little doubt that this bloated tale of the 10th Hunger Games goes on far too long and has to rely on secondary characters for any interesting bit that happens on the screen.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: Ballad is a satisfying, well-acted melodrama with moral gray areas and real stakes for its characters.
reviews.author: Esther Zuckerman

reviews.text: I find this to be the most sustained piece of filmmaking in the entire Hunger Games series, a stand-alone installment with a satisfying self-contained story for its new heroine.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: [The film] reminds us that the Hunger Games franchise is one of the best, most thoughtful of all YA franchises. It’s capably directed, faithfully adapted, and features some brilliant performances from Davis, Schwartzman, and Dinklage.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: The latest entry is not only one of the better installments, but this is a compelling and morally complex blockbuster. The final act loses steam, but it works overall.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: Snow’s evolution from war-scarred orphan to what Donald Sutherland is playing in the original quadrilogy is rendered as blank as, well, snow.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes perhaps is even better than the first movie with Jennifer Lawrence. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: Great chemistry with Zegler & Blyth & really enjoyed supporting roles from Dinklage, Schafer and Viola Davis was EXCELLENT as the villain. It loses monumental at a certain point & some elements are not fully realized but overall a film worth watching!
reviews.author: Elliott Collins

reviews.text: Our world so hauntingly echoes Collins’s fictions that the film, shot last summer, moves us to spend its gargantuan running time reflecting on contemporary headlines, mourning the generational tragedy of anger and fear begetting anger and fear.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: In its more bonkers moments, Songbirds and Snakes looks and sounds like the cast of Oklahoma are putting on a production of Gladiator in a fever-dream set inside a panto – and I am here for it.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: The screenplay hits all the key beats from the novel, only trimming the fat to focus more on Corio and Lucy’s relationship.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: However flimsy the pretext, Lawrence treats it with respect, mining tension and momentum.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: A surprisingly suspenseful prequel.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: Set some sixtyish years prior to the adventures of Katniss Everdeen, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is both an Easter egg-littered prequel to the YA franchise and a messy, unnecessary origin story for its primary villain.
reviews.author: Brent Hankins

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes takes place 64 years earlier but offers more of the same, for better or worse.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: You’ll want to volunteer as tribute if you’re a fan of The Hunger Games as the new prequel movie The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is an equally thrilling entry in the franchise.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: [T]he resulting film is a gripping, unsettling character study and, as a result, easily the best installment in the movie series.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Instead of a thrilling game of survival, these games are a slog to get through.
reviews.author: Andrew Parker

reviews.text: Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler are phenomenal, each crafting personas that elicit sympathy and ire, layering complexities with tremendous charisma to their nuanced performances.
reviews.author: Chris Joyce

reviews.text: This is a prequel with familiar intense elements but slithers and sings when it transforms into something more character-driven and thematically harsher that eventually no longer resembles a YA story
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: This book-to-movie romantic fantasy makes up for its jerky pacing with strong action and scene-stealing performances from Davis and Dinklage.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: ... This adaptation manages not to dilute everything that is powerful and interesting about Suzanne Collins' novels. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a thoroughly mediocre (and overlong, at 2 hours and 37 minutes) return to the world of The Hunger Games, with the only saving grace being that it’s a one-off event with no current plans for more films.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: If the artistic result is not too encouraging, the box office numbers will dictate whether this inglorious return has been a short-lived effort or, as expected, the franchise will continue to be squeezed to its last drop. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: It’s not perfect but it does enough to add more texture to the Hunger Games universe.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: At a punishing running time of over two and a half hours – during which the movie switches between overcomplicating a simple premise and overstaying a slender welcome – it often feels as there never will be a tomorrow.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: It’s grandiose, kooky, and sometimes cruel. But despite being adapted from a YA book, this gray universe still feels refreshingly adult in our own modern multiplex land of bread and circuses.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: Songbirds and Snakes takes its job Super-seriously, with more solemnity than imaginative excitement.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: The odds were not in its favor.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: “The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes,” unlike the stellar predecessors of the series, feels curiously starved for real insights into the opposing shades of the human soul.
reviews.author: Tomris Laffly

reviews.text: It's been over a decade since Katniss Everdeen first graced the big screen and "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" misses too many notes to live up to its predecessor's achievements.
reviews.author: Meredith G. White

reviews.text: Though there are strong supporting performances from Peter Dinklage, Viola Davis, and Jason Schwartzman, Zegler is the key. Even when the film itself starts to increasingly hit false notes, Zegler never does.
reviews.author: Chase Hutchinson

reviews.text: Surprisingly, The Ballad Of Songbirds And Snakes only improves on the films that came before it. It’s such a satisfying prequel and one of the best villain origin stories we’ve seen lately.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: Like the Hunger Games themselves, the film isn’t so much entertainment as it is an exercise in survival.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes successfully explores the origins Hunger Games villain President Snow, though the sum is greater than its parts.
reviews.author: Michael Balderston

reviews.text: Despite some interesting action scenes, the movie is far too long at two hours and 40 minutes. Worse yet, you’re always aware that you’re watching a movie.  Even the title is too long.
reviews.author: Liz Braun

reviews.text: As far as cynically motivated prequels go—more monetary than creative—it's the best I've seen in a while (certainly superior to Peter Jackson's “The Hobbit” trilogy). Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Predictably passionless and  derivative, but at least it’s not harmful to the series as a whole.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: A 'Start of Darkness' sci-fi franchise prequel where we learn how convoluted political machinations and doomed romance led the series' main villain to evolve out of a tall moody sad boy with the personality of driftwood? Wonder how he feels about sand...
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: While the film lectures you about audiences craving emotional connections to their violence, it seemingly forgets to connect you to the characters or violence.
reviews.author: EJ Moreno

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes undercuts a legacy that defined an era of young adult literature...
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: Even though the poison took a long time to seep in for this prequel, in the end Snow lands on top. Not a perfect Snow white success by any means, but pearly enough for the fans.
reviews.author: Christie Cronan

reviews.text: Ultimately, there’s far too many questions asked here left unanswered.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: … subverts the conventions of its predecessors to create a work of glorious and heart-breaking ego death.
reviews.author: Cain Noble-Davies

reviews.text: The glue holding it all together is its steadfast portrayal of the cynicism and emotional neglect required to regard other human beings as numbers and meat that have to be placated to be useful.
reviews.author: Justin Clark

reviews.text: In the central role, it’s Blyth’s task to make sense of Coriolanus Snow’s journey, and he does.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: This movie is ABSOLUTELY incredible, a top-tier Hunger Games Movie, that makes me just as excited as when I saw Catching Fire!
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: Bad, in a surprising, unique way.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: The biggest strengths of this prequel are the details and history from The Hunger Games series that it fills in and Tom Blyth shining in the central role of Coriolanus Snow, providing a simultaneously tragic and infuriating villain origin story.
reviews.author: Aaron White

reviews.text: I have three words to describe this film - long, silly, and dark.
reviews.author: Joseph Robinson

reviews.text: It has a few laughs and some stylish outfits, but this is unfortunately a shallow prequel, one which fails to breathe new life into the Hunger Games franchise.
reviews.author: Hanna Flint

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes takes audiences back to dystopian Panem in a bleak and  violent prequel. The origin of villain Coriolanus Snow is a dark journey of desperate ambition evolving to utter ruthlessness.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: With so many choices being made to accommodate for backstory, how the Hunger Games play out, and what the fallout from that would be, I found it impressive to be able to take in so much and feel as pleased as I was with where we leave these characters.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: Another rock solid addition to the film franchise. Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes loses some steam in the last chapter, but the first two are phenomenal, and the cast is on point. Tom Blyth excels playing a protagonist with a deteriorating moral compass.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Diehard fans of The Hunger Games will find a lot to enjoy, and the film is definitely more entertaining than the Mockingjay films. Still, The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes remains an engaging (if overlong) watch, that doesn’t quite justify its existence.
reviews.author: Chelsea Steiner

reviews.text: Yes, you can be commercial and unnecessary while at the same time setting up interesting ideas and showing singular charisma and style. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Randy Meeks

reviews.text: Thanks to its important themes, brilliant performances and solid production values, this is one of the best installments of its franchise. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juan Jose Cruz

reviews.text: Ballad Of Songbirds And Snakes squanders a potentially rich premise and winds up as a stock-issue Romeo and Juliet riff with nothing new for the die-hard faithful or the curious newcomers.
reviews.author: Eric Francisco

reviews.text: The visuals are incredible, the score heightens the intensity to level eleven, and the acting is all top notch — as expected with this phenomenal cast. Too much singing, but that comes right from the book.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: I left the screening feeling like I needed a prequel to this prequel, so I would finally understand who the film’s protagonist actually is.
reviews.author: Serena Seghedoni

reviews.text: [An] intriguing and well-acted prequel that thankfully doesn’t feel like a cash grab trying to capitalise on the popularity of the franchise.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: Exploring the Capitol and getting a closer look at how the Games are made are the more interesting parts of the movie. (…) But there is a part that takes another path that is way less captivating. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jesus Agudo

reviews.text: One of the best 'The Hunger Games' films. Coriolanus Snow's rise to power story is well executed by F. Lawrence in this colder, twistier and more interesting prequel. Rachel Zegler is phenomenal as feisty Lucy Gray Baird. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Better than it ought to be, yet still significantly short of greatness, it might have made a superior start to a saga if we didn't already have the finish.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: An anemic, meandering, clunky and overlong bore. Viola Davis is the film's MVP.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: A perfectly fine Hunger Games movie. Based on Suzanne Collins' prequel novel, it makes up for a lack of familiar characters with provocative themes.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: Though the movie successfully hits the over-500-page book's broad strokes, in doing so, it results in an overstuffed, hollowed-out adaptation that plays more like two movies than one by the time it gets to its third act.
reviews.author: Kirsten Acuna

reviews.text: This rote affair would deserve the designation “for fans only,” if not for the sneaking suspicion that even they won’t be wowed by this return trip to Panem.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: All the elements that made the Hunger Games a success are there — the dark political metaphors, the horrifying dystopian premise, the beautiful actors who make the whole bitter pill easier to swallow — but Songbirds and Snakes feels simply like a rehash.
reviews.author: Hoai-Tran Bui

reviews.text: If your stomach has been rumbling these past eight years for another portion of The Hunger Games, Lionsgate have rustled one up from Suzanne Collins’s 2020 prequel novel, and the vibe is very much: sorry, but this is what we had in the fridge.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Ultimately, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes could have delivered a more compelling narrative, but it does do the job of a franchise movie and bring us back to a familiar world so we can once more take a look around.
reviews.author: Rotem Rusak

reviews.text: Whether “The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes” is enough to relight those embers remains to be seen, but it is a reminder how good a platform they offered young actors. It’s a ritual worth returning to.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: Tom Blyth & Viola Davis make this prequel sing. This is the best Hunger Games movie since Catching Fire, and worth another trip to the arena.
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: The lore of the Hunger Games is so wacky you simply have to respect it.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Even devotees of Collins’s book might walk away from this adaptation calloused and confused, so rushed does the final turn of Corio’s screw feel.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: Songbirds and Snakes is divided into three chapters, and there’s something heart-sinking about realizing that, after the Hunger Games sequence plays out, the movie still has one more chapter to go.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is captivating through and through, capturing the magic that made The Hunger Games such a sensation while delivering a darker, more nuanced look at the corruption at the heart of Panem.
reviews.author: Belen Edwards

reviews.text: Actors Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler are brilliant additions to the franchise with equally magnetic takes on their very different characters, but aren’t given enough time to fully flesh them out.
reviews.author: Emma Stefansky

reviews.text: Rachel Zegler is a scene stealer in The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes but the third act completely derails the film and feels like a rushed ending to a different movie.
reviews.author: Daniel Baptista

reviews.text: Imagine if “The Phantom Menace” was better than every episode of George Lucas’ original “Star Wars” trilogy.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes shows us what happens if we get too carried away by propaganda, luxury, and the promise of safety. In that way, it’s a fitting end to the franchise — and a fitting end to the way the genre evolved into a beast of its own.
reviews.author: Petrana Radulovic

reviews.text: This movie finally ties itself into various knots to prefigure the later world of Katniss, but the time to end the Games came long ago.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is an effective return to the cautionary tale that is Panem.
reviews.author: Tara Bennett

reviews.text: The biggest reason why this movie sings is because Rachel Zegler is in it as Lucy Gray Baird.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: Make no mistake: "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" lives and dies on the strength of Rachel Zegler's sheer force of will
reviews.author: Jeremy Mathai

reviews.text: The film is daring, engaging, tense, and even occasionally funny. It's no easy feat to make a prequel that's just as good, if not better, than the films that came before. It is faithful to the book and showcases one of the best casts of the year.
reviews.author: Jamie Jirak

reviews.text: By focusing on the gray between the good and the bad, and with a scale and scope that the other films never quite had, The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes might just be the most engrossing film in this series.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: The fact it can get you invested in so many obnoxious teens with silly haircuts and sillier names may be an achievement in itself.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: A muddled but grimly compelling prequel to the hit franchise.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: Feels like a natural extension of the saga, balancing bloodsport, endangered young love and a heightened level of political commentary that respects the intelligence of young audiences as only Collins can.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: If only there were something truly new and innovative about this chapter to fully justify resurrecting the Hunger Games franchise eight years after Mockingjay — Part 2.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: Nicely knotty themes of trust and mistrust snake through the tangled plot, writhing and biting. And the low-tech games themselves are grimly gripping, with pitchforks, poison, drones, and deadly reptiles all cruelly deployed.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: It’s the origin story of Panem’s chief sociopath, president Coriolanus Snow (played by Donald Sutherland in the original films), that instead feels like the yassification of a future monster.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: With top-notch performances and production design, The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a worthy addition to the Hunger Games franchise.
reviews.author: Rachel LaBonte

reviews.text: One of the more radical franchise blockbusters to have emerged in quite some time, positively reminiscent of the recent "Star Wars" series "Andor" in how it explores the foundations of a rebellion viewers know is doomed to fail.
reviews.author: Alistair Ryder

reviews.text: As soon as Peter Dinklage announced the new games, I settled into my seat, grabbed a handful of popcorn, and prepared myself to be entertained. I wasn’t disappointed.
reviews.author: Anna Menta

reviews.text: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is long, which means that it sometimes lags, but its cast and the well-crafted visuals keep it as entertaining as possible.
reviews.author: Emily Zemler

reviews.text: Above all, “The Ballad of Songbird & Snakes” is an impressive movie-going experience (IMAX is recommended) that offers a thought-provoking discussion on how society and ideology can influence someone — a central theme of the franchise.
reviews.author: Lauren LaMagna

reviews.text: It has retained the impact of the other Hunger Games movies and the setting invigorates certain aspects to bring a fresh take to this world while still delivering everything fans would want.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

synopsis: Experience the story of THE HUNGER GAMES -- 64 years before Katniss Everdeen volunteered as tribute, and decades before Coriolanus Snow became the tyrannical President of Panem. THE HUNGER GAMES: THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS & SNAKES follows a young Coriolanus (Tom Blyth) who is the last hope for his failing lineage, the once-proud Snow family that has fallen from grace in a post-war Capitol. With his livelihood threatened, Snow is reluctantly assigned to mentor Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler), a tribute from the impoverished District 12. But after Lucy Gray's charm captivates the audience of Panem, Snow sees an opportunity to shift their fates. With everything he has worked for hanging in the balance, Snow unites with Lucy Gray to turn the odds in their favor. Battling his instincts for both good and evil, Snow sets out on a race against time to survive and reveal if he will ultimately become a songbird or a snake.
